verse.text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the command of God our Savior and Christ Jesus our hope,
to Timothy, my true-born child in the faith: Grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
Just as I urged you to stay in Ephesus when I was traveling to Macedonia, I do so now, so that you may command certain people not to teach foreign doctrines
nor to devote themselves to myths and endless genealogies. These things produce empty speculations rather than the household management of God, which operates by faith.
The goal of this command is love that flows from a pure heart, a good conscience, and a faith that is not a performance.
Some people, having missed the mark in these things, have wandered off into empty talk.
They want to be teachers of the Law, yet they understand neither what they are saying nor the things about which they make such confident assertions.
Now we know that the Law is good if one uses it lawfully.

This requires understanding that law is not laid down for a just person, but for the lawless and rebellious, for the ungodly and sinners, for the unholy and profane, for those who kill their fathers or mothers, for murderers,
for the sexually immoral, for men who bed men, for slave-traders, for liars, for perjurers, and for whatever else stands against healthy teaching.
This teaching is in accordance with the good news of the glory of the blessed God, with which I was entrusted.
I am grateful to Christ Jesus our Lord, who has empowered me, because he considered me trustworthy, appointing me to his service,
even though I was formerly a slanderer, a persecutor, and an insolent aggressor. But I was shown mercy because I acted in the ignorance of unbelief,
and the grace of our Lord overflowed with the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
This is a trustworthy saying, worthy of full acceptance: “Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners”—of whom I am the foremost.
But for this very reason I was shown mercy, so that in me, the foremost, Christ Jesus might demonstrate his total patience as a prototype for those who were going to believe in him for eternal life.
Now to the King of the ages, the incorruptible, invisible, only God, be honor and glory forever and ever. Amen.
This command I entrust to you, Timothy, my child, in accordance with the prophecies previously made about you, so that by them you may fight the good campaign,
holding on to faith and a good conscience. By rejecting their conscience, some have shipwrecked their faith.
Among them are Hymenaeus and Alexander, whom I have handed over to Satan so that they may be disciplined not to blaspheme.
I urge, then, first of all, that petitions, prayers, intercessions, and thanksgivings be made for all people—
for kings and all those who hold high office—so that we may lead a tranquil and quiet life in all devotion and dignity.
This is good and pleasing in the sight of God our Savior,
who desires all people to be saved and to come to a full recognition of the truth.
For there is one God, and one mediator between God and humanity: the man, Christ Jesus,
who gave himself as a ransom-price for everyone—the testimony given at the proper time.
For this purpose I was appointed a herald and an apostle—I am telling the truth, I am not lying—a teacher of the nations in faithfulness and truth.
Therefore, I want the men in every place to pray, lifting up devout hands without anger or disputing.
Likewise, I want the women to adorn themselves in respectable demeanor, with modesty and self-mastery, not with elaborate hair-braiding and gold or pearls or expensive clothing,
but by means of good works, as is appropriate for women who profess a reverence for God.
Let a woman learn in quietness with all submissiveness.
I do not permit a woman to teach or to dictate to a man; instead, she is to remain in quietness.
For Adam was formed first, then Eve;
and Adam was not the one deceived, but the woman, having been completely deceived, fell into transgression.
Yet she will be preserved through the Child-bearing, provided they continue in faithfulness, love, and holiness, with self-mastery.
This saying is trustworthy: if someone aspires to the role of an overseer, they desire a noble work.
Therefore, the overseer must be beyond reproach, a man faithful to one woman, clear-headed, self-controlled, orderly in conduct, hospitable, and skilled at teaching.
He must not be a heavy drinker or a bully, but instead be gentle and yielding, not looking for a fight, and not a lover of money.
He must manage his own household well, keeping his children in a state of respectful cooperation with all dignity.
(For if someone does not know how to manage their own household, how will they take care of God’s assembly?)
He must not be a recent convert, so that he does not become blinded by conceit and fall into the same judgment as the Slanderer.
Furthermore, he must have a good reputation among those on the outside, so that he does not fall into disgrace and into the Slanderer’s trap.
Servant-ministers, likewise, must be people of dignity, not double-tongued, not addicted to much wine, and not greedy for dishonest gain.
They must hold the mystery of the faith with a clean conscience.
Let these also be scrutinized first; then, if they are found to be beyond accusation, let them serve as ministers.
The women, likewise, must be dignified, not slanderers, but clear-headed and faithful in all things.
Servant-ministers should be men faithful to one woman, managing their children and their own households well.
For those who have served well as ministers gain for themselves a noble standing and great confidence in the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
I am writing these things to you, hoping to come to you soon.
But if I am delayed, I write so that you may know how it is necessary to conduct oneself in God’s household, which is the assembly of the living God, the pillar and support of the truth.

Beyond all dispute, great is the mystery of our devotion: He was revealed in the flesh, was vindicated by the Spirit, was seen by angels, was proclaimed among the nations, was believed on in the world, was taken up in glory.
Now the Spirit explicitly says that in later times some will depart from the faith, devoting themselves to deceptive spirits and the teachings of demons
through the acting of liars who are branded in their own consciences.
These people forbid marriage and demand abstinence from foods that God created to be received with thanksgiving by those who are faithful and have fully recognized the truth.
For every creation of God is good, and nothing is to be rejected if it is received with thanksgiving,
because it is set apart as holy through the word of God and prayerful petition.
If you lay these things before the brothers and sisters, you will be a good servant of Christ Jesus, nourished by the words of the faith and the good teaching you have followed closely.
But reject godless and senile myths. Instead, train yourself for godly devotion.
For while physical training is beneficial for a little, godly devotion is beneficial for everything, since it holds a promise of life—both for the present and the one to come.
This saying is trustworthy and worthy of full acceptance:

text.q: "For to this end we labor and face reproach, because we have set our hope on a living God, who is the Savior of all people, especially of those who are faithful."

verse.text: Command these things and teach them.
Let no one look down on your youth, but become a pattern for the faithful in your speech, in your way of life, in love, in faith, and in purity.
Until I arrive, devote yourself to the public reading of Scripture, to exhortation, and to teaching.
Do not neglect the spiritual gift within you, which was given to you through prophecy with the laying on of hands by the council of elders.
Practice these things; be absorbed in them, so that your progress may be evident to all.
Keep a close watch on yourself and on the teaching. Persist in these things, for by doing so you will save both yourself and those who hear you.
Do not harshly rebuke an older man, but appeal to him as you would a father. Treat younger men as brothers,
older women as mothers, and younger women as sisters, with absolute moral purity.
Honor widows who are truly widows—those who are genuinely alone.

But if any widow has children or grandchildren, let them first learn to practice their devotion toward their own household and to make a return of care to their parents and grandparents, for this is acceptable in the sight of God.
The woman who is truly a widow and left entirely alone has fixed her hope on God and persists in petitions and prayers night and day.
But the woman who lives for self-indulgent pleasure is dead even while she lives.
Command these things as well, so that they may be beyond reproach.
If anyone does not provide for his own people, and especially for the members of his own household, he has denied the faith and is worse than an unbeliever.
A widow should be enrolled on the official list only if she is at least sixty years old, has been a "one-man woman,"

and is well-attested for good works: if she has raised children, if she has shown hospitality to strangers, if she has washed the feet of the holy ones, if she has assisted those in distress, if she has devoted herself to every kind of good work.
But refuse to enroll younger widows. For when their physical desires pull them away from Christ, they want to marry,
incurring judgment because they have set aside their initial pledge of faithfulness.
At the same time, they also learn to be idle, wandering from house to house; and not only idle, but also gossips and busybodies, saying things they should not.
Therefore, I want younger widows to marry, bear children, manage their households, and give the adversary no opportunity for slander.
For some have already turned aside to follow Satan.
If any believing woman has widows in her family, let her assist them so that the church is not burdened, and can assist those who are truly widows.
Elders who lead well should be considered worthy of double honor, especially those who labor to the point of exhaustion in preaching and teaching.
For the Scripture says, “You shall not muzzle an ox while it is treading out the grain,” and, “The worker is worthy of his wages.”
Do not accept an accusation against an elder unless it is supported by two or three witnesses.
Rebuke those who persist in sin in the presence of everyone, so that the rest may also stand in awe.
I solemnly charge you before God and Christ Jesus and the chosen angels to keep these instructions without prejudice, doing nothing out of partiality.
verse.note: This likely refers to the angels who remained faithful to God (in contrast to fallen angels) or specific angels viewed as witnesses to the administration of the church.

verse.text: Do not lay hands on anyone hastily, and do not share in the sins of others; keep yourself pure.
verse.note: In the context of the chapter's focus on elders and sin, this refers either to the ordination of new leaders or the formal reinstatement of a repentant person. The warning is to avoid rushing into such endorsements.

verse.text: No longer drink only water, but use a little wine for the sake of your stomach and your frequent illnesses.
The sins of some people are obvious, preceding them to judgment, but for others, their sins follow behind.
In the same way, good works are also obvious; and even those that are otherwise cannot remain hidden.
Let all those who are slaves under a yoke consider their own masters worthy of full honor, so that the name of God and our teaching may not be slandered.

Those who have believing masters must not look down on them because they are brothers; rather, they should serve them even better, because those who benefit from their good service are believers and beloved. Teach and urge these things.
If anyone teaches a different doctrine and does not align themselves with healthy words—those of our Lord Jesus Christ—and the teaching that accords with piety,
they are clouded by conceit and understand nothing. Instead, they have an unhealthy obsession with controversies and battles over words, which give rise to envy, strife, slanders, evil suspicions,
and constant friction among people who are corrupted in their minds and robbed of the truth, imagining that piety is a means of financial gain.
Of course, piety with contentment is a great means of gain.
For we brought nothing into the world, because we cannot take anything out of it either.
But if we have food and shelter, we will be satisfied with these.
Those who desire to be rich fall into temptation and a snare and many mindless and harmful desires, which plunge people into ruin and destruction.
For a root of all kinds of evils is the love of money, and by reaching out for it, some have wandered away from the faith and pierced themselves through with many griefs.
But you, O man of God, flee from these things. Instead, pursue justice, piety, faith, love, endurance, and gentle-heartedness.
Compete in the good contest of the faith; take hold of the eternal life to which you were called and for which you made the good confession in the presence of many witnesses.
I charge you in the presence of God, who gives life to all things, and of Christ Jesus, who testified the good confession before Pontius Pilate,
to keep the commandment unspotted and irreproachable until the appearing of our Lord Jesus Christ,
which the blessed and only Sovereign will reveal at the proper time—the King of those who reign and Lord of those who exercise lordship,
the only one who possesses immortality, dwelling in unapproachable light, whom no human has seen or is able to see. To him be honor and eternal might. Amen.
Command those who are rich in the present age not to be arrogant, nor to set their hope on the uncertainty of wealth, but on God, who richly provides us with everything for our enjoyment.
Tell them to do good, to be rich in good works, to be generous and ready to share,
storing up for themselves a good foundation for the future, so that they may take hold of the life that is truly life.
O Timothy, guard the sacred deposit entrusted to you. Turn away from the profane empty-talk and contradictions of what is falsely called “Knowledge,”
which some, by professing it, have missed the mark concerning the faith. Grace be with you all.
